Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Ultrafast spintronic devices based on magnetic tunnel junctions using magnesium oxide (MgO) tunnel barriers
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will develop an ultrafast solid-state magnetic sensor using MgO-based magnetic tunneling junction (MTJ). The operating frequency range will span from DC to 2 GHz, the broadest among competing technologies. The sensor will have a compact size and high sensitivity and will operate at ambient conditions with no supporting system. The ability to mass produce these devices will provide a significant cost advantage.

There is a critical unmet need in ultrafast sensors. These sensors can perform non-destructive evaluation (NDE) of VLSI semiconductor chips, aircraft components and engine turbines, they will allow computers to process information faster in data storage devices, and they can be used to measure fast currents in devices such as antenna. The sensors hold great promise for monitoring the health of aircrafts. Ultrafast sensors can also monitor the performance of VLSI in failure analysis, enhancing the competitiveness of the semiconductor industry by shortening the development cycles. Knowledge gained in ultrafast sensor can be used to make faster data storage devices and build better national defense infrastructure.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project, an ultrafast solid-state magnetic sensor using MgO-based magnetic tunneling junction (MTJ) was developed. These MTJ sensors have a compact size of less than 1 mm2 with various form factors and a broad operating frequency range. The developed technology features a combination of characteristics which make them an attractive alternative to other magnetic sensors on the market. We have relied on the spin-orbit coupling in the magnetic free layer of the sensors to increase the magnetic damping constant for high frequency application. We have researched and developed understanding of the magnetic shot noise which is the dominant magnetic noise at high frequency. The Fano factor of shot noise was determined to be 0.55 in the sensor configuration. We have developed micromagnetics simulation software to simulate the sensor behavior at high frequency. The software can also be used to simulate magnetic hysteresis and field sensitivity according to sensor shapes and geometry. The MTJ sensors operate at ambient conditions with no supporting system. The ability to produce these devices in quantity has given us cost advantage. These sensors can perform non-destructive evaluation (NDE) of VLSI semiconductor chips, and be used for medical application such as in magnetic resonance imaging. Our experimental methods included magnetron sputtering, clean-room processing, magnetotransport studies, and magnetometry. We have obtained new structures and compositions in MTJ, for high frequency response.

Our sensors have great promise for monitoring the health of aircrafts. The efficient NDE testing using MTJs can save lives by detecting defects early. Ultrafast sensors can also monitor the performance of VLSI in failure analysis, enhancing the competitiveness of the semiconductor industry by shortening the development cycles.  Knowledge gained in ultrafast sensor can be used to make faster data storage devices and build better national defense infrastructure. Our research has addressed some fundamental questions in the science and technology of spintronics. It has trained human resources who have gained much experience in condensed matter physics, magnetic sensing, and manufacturing of solid-state magnetic sensors. We have provided internships to high school students and college students, which have led some of these students finding employments in technology sectors. Our effort in the development of ultrafast sensors has generated societal, educational and scientific benefits. Our research has led to increased scientific understanding and promising applications.

 


Last Modified: 04/03/2014
Modified by: Matthew J Carter
